question.statement: How did we define the slope of the secant line between two points (a,f(a)) and (x,f(x))?

definition.title: Slope of the Tangent Line 1
definition.p: The tangent line to a curve y=f(x) at the point P(a(f(a)) is the line through the point P with slope \ds m=\lim_{x\to a} \dfrac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a}, provided that this limit exists.

example.statement: Find the slope of the tangent line through the points (a,f(a))) and (a+h,(f(a+h))

definition.title: Slope of the Tangent Line 2
definition.p: The tangent line to a curve y=f(x) at the point P(a,f(a)) is the line through the point P with slope \ds m = \lim_{h\to 0} \dfrac{f(a+h)-f(a)}{h}, provided that this limit exists, where h is considered to be a small change in x.

assemblage.title: Instantaneous Velocity
assemblage.p: The instantaneous velocity of an object, given its position function f(x), is \ds v(a) = \lim_{h\to 0} \dfrac{f(a+h)-f(a)}{h}

subsubsection.title: Derivatives

definition.title: The Derivative (at x=a)

subsubsection.p:
We have two ways of interpreting what the derivative actually means:
The derivative f'(a) is the instantaneous rate of change of y=f(x) wish respect to x when x=a.
The derivative f'(a) is equal to the slope of the tangent line to the function y=f(x) at the point (a,f(a)).

subsubsection.title: Rates of Change
subsubsection.p:
If we use the function y = f(x), then the derivative tells us the rate of change of the output y with respect to the input x. Another way of writing this is
\text{instantaneous ROC } = \lim_{\Delta x\to 0} \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \lim_{x_2\to x_1}\dfrac{f(x_2)-f(x_1)}{x_2-x_1}
